Applicative functors serve as an intermediate structure between functors and monads, allowing for sequenced computations without the use of prior results in subsequent ones. They are known as Closed Monoidal Functors in Category Theory and are equivalent to lax monoidal functors with tensorial strength. Introduced in 2008, they are now implemented in various languages including Haskell, Idris, and F#. While monads in Haskell are also applicative functors, this is not always the case in Category Theory.

A bit field is a data structure made up of adjacent bits allocated for specific purposes, allowing individual bits or groups to be set or inspected. It is commonly used to represent integral types like single-bit Booleans. The meaning of each bit is determined by the programmer, often used to represent attributes. CPUs use collections of bit fields called flags to control or indicate outcomes of operations. Processors have a status register with flags that can influence subsequent operations. Bit fields differ from bit arrays, which store a large set of bits indexed by integers. Bit fields typically fit within a machine word and have independent denotation of bits from their numerical index.

In functional programming, a monad combines program fragments and wraps their return values in a type with additional computation. Monads define operators to wrap values and compose functions. They are used to reduce boilerplate code, abstract control flow, and manage side-effects. The concept of a monad originates from category theory, where it is defined as a functor with additional structure. Monads help unify various computer-science problems and have formal requirements known as the monad laws. They make semantics explicit and can be used to implement convenient language features. Haskell offers pre-built definitions for monads in its core libraries.

Recursion in computer science involves solving problems by breaking them down into smaller instances of the same problem. This is done by using functions that call themselves within their own code. Recursion is a fundamental concept in computer science, allowing for the definition of infinite sets and computations through finite statements and programs. While most programming languages support recursion, some functional languages rely solely on recursion for looping. Despite its power, recursion may not always be the most efficient solution due to potential memory issues, but techniques like tail call optimization can help improve performance in certain cases.

content: A syntax error is a mistake in the way characters are arranged in a programming language. In compiled languages, these errors are found during compilation, while in interpreted languages, they may be found during execution. There is debate over what constitutes a syntax error, with some considering things like using an uninitialized variable in Java as a syntax error. In 8-bit home computers using BASIC, the SYNTAX ERROR message was infamous for indicating a parsing problem. Syntax errors can also happen on calculators when inputting invalid equations, like unclosed brackets or multiple decimal points.

content: Syntax highlighting is a text editor feature used for programming, scripting, or markup languages like HTML. It shows text, particularly source code, in different colors and fonts based on term categories. This helps with writing in structured languages by making structures and syntax errors visually clear. It is used in programming manuals and websites to help readers understand code snippets easily. Syntax highlighting does not change the text's meaning, it is for human readers only. It is a form of secondary notation that reinforces text meaning. Some

content: The Java syntax is derived from C and C++, with all code belonging to classes and values being objects. Primitive types are not considered objects for performance reasons, but can be converted to objects. Features like operator overloading and unsigned integer types are omitted for simplicity and to prevent errors. The syntax has been extended over the years to support capabilities like generic programming and lambda expressions. New JDK versions are released twice a year with incremental improvements to the language.

content: Ad hoc polymorphism in programming allows polymorphic functions to work with different types of arguments, resulting in multiple implementations based on argument type. Also known as function or operator overloading, it is not a fundamental type system feature. In contrast, parametric polymorphism applies a single abstract implementation to multiple types transparently. Christopher Strachey introduced this classification in 1967.

content: In formal language theory, a context-free grammar (CFG) consists of production rules that can be applied to a nonterminal symbol regardless of its context. Each rule has the form 𝐴 → 𝛼, where 𝐴 is a single nonterminal symbol and 𝛼 is a string of terminals and/or nonterminals. Context-free grammars generate context-free languages (CFL), which can be described using phrase structure grammars in linguistics or Backus-Naur form (BNF) in computer science. Different CFGs can generate the same CFL, highlighting the distinction between language properties and grammar properties. Context-free grammars are used in linguistics to analyze natural language sentence structure and in computer science to define programming languages and XML structures.

A programming domain refers to a set of programming languages or environments designed for a specific subject or category. Examples include expert systems, natural-language processing, computer vision, and more. Other domains include application scripting, artificial intelligence reasoning, cloud computing, and image processing, among others. Each domain focuses on functions relevant to that subject or category, omitting irrelevant functions. This article explores various programming domains and their applications in different fields such as finance, education, and entertainment.

EOPL is a textbook on programming languages by Daniel P. Friedman, Mitchell Wand, and Christopher T. Haynes focusing on principles from an operational perspective. It begins with an interpreter in Scheme for a functional core language, gradually adding constructs to increase expressive power. The second part shows how to systematically translate interpreters into register machines, simplifying them to tail-recursive function calls for easy translation into C or assembly. The book also covers systematic transformations and pre-computations, preparing readers for courses on compilation and language translation. Originally started in 1983 at Indiana University, EOPL has become a near-classic with its third edition now incorporating additional topics such as types and modules. The book has influenced related texts like Queinnec's Lisp in Small Pieces and Krishnamurthi's Programming Languages: Application and Interpretation.

content: In computer science, expressive power refers to a language's ability to represent and communicate ideas. Languages with greater expressiveness can convey a wider range of concepts. For example, OWL2 EL is less expressive than OWL2 RL because it lacks certain features like negation. This trade-off allows for more efficient reasoning in OWL2 EL, making it better suited for pr

Function composition in computer science involves combining simple functions to create more complex ones by passing the result of each function as the argument of the next. This concept mirrors mathematical function composition. Programmers frequently use this technique to build efficient and maintainable code, and almost all programming languages support it. Languages with first-class functions make it easier to define and use composite functions. By breaking functions into smaller pieces, developers can enhance code reuse and maintainability. Function composition can also be applied to creating entire programs. While

A high-level language computer architecture (HLLCA) is designed for a specific high-level programming language (HLL) rather than hardware considerations. Coined in the 1960s, HLLCAs were popular until the 1980s when Intel 432 failed. Optimizing compilers and RISC architectures replaced HLLCAs. Burroughs large systems in 1961 were among the first HLLCAs for ALGOL 60. Lisp machines in the 1970s and 1980s were designed for Lisp. Java processors are the most popular HLLCAs today, used for specific applications. HSA (2012) is a recent architecture with HSAIL providing support for HLL features using JIT for performance. A detailed survey and critique of HLLCAs can be found in Ditzel & Patterson (1980).

Homoiconicity in computer programming refers to languages where programs can be manipulated as data within the language itself. This property, found in languages like Lisp and Clojure, simplifies metaprogramming by allowing code to be treated as data structures. This makes it easier to implement features like syntactic macros and dynamic reflection at runtime. Homoiconic languages like Lisp use S-expressions as their primary data structure, enabling concise program transformations. Other examples of homoiconic languages include Clojure, Rebol, Refal, Prolog, and possibly Julia.
